Anyone have any tips on how to train for biking at (higher) altitudes, to prevent altitude sickness? We are planning a trip to Nepal and they warn for altitude sickness. We live in Holland, which is as flat as can be. Thanks for the tips üôèüèª
Do you have time to spend a day acclimating when you get there before you start riding?

data.text: Sleep as low as possible. I don't know how high you are going but I started a tour in Chengdu which is low. The road quickly goes up to 4500m. I tried to acclimatize by riding without panniers up to 3000m as fast as I could. Then started on the trip sleeping once at 2000m and then 4000m. If you can't do that then sleeping around 800m above the previous day I think is recommended.

data.text: Everyone responds differently to high altitude. Some affected more than others. So please be careful if it's your first time. Ascend slowly. Sleep lower than you climb to. Drink lots of water and if you get a headache descend.

data.text: Your body will let you know, but at least the altitude won‚Äôt take as large of a toll. We saw people in Peru that obviously were not in even mediocre shape struggling at 11,000‚Äô, and they were positively suffering above 13,000‚Äô. We lived at and came from sea level but trained (hiking steep trails) for 6 months prior and think it helped immensely. I only had mild AMS once for a few hours at 14k and it passed with some aspirin. I did a lot of researcher beforehand, including lots of great info from this site, and listened to local guides as well as our own bodies. While we were in decent shape, once we hit 10k (flying in) we noticed we had to slow things down to avoid getting winded fast, so we did. We took 2 days beforehand to acclimatize based on the recommendations here and think that helped a lot. But one of the things we also learned is that everyone is different. We since moved to 5,000‚Äô elevation and I find mountain biking over 8,000‚Äô is noticeable, so there are different levels.

data.text: I‚Äôm not understanding the distinction you‚Äôre drawing between ‚Äúrespiratory‚Äù and ‚Äúpulmonary‚Äù here. I‚Äôve always felt they were largely synonymous‚Ä¶ Can you elaborate a bit?
data.author: Zack Martinez

data.text: Respiratory action is what you described, that is the act of inspiration and expiration when we breathe. Pulmonary action is the actual exchange of gases - primarily O2 and CO2 - while we are breathing. This gas exchange isn't mechanical like respiration. Respiration uses our diaphragm muscle to pull air in and our ribcage muscles to push air out. Our pulmonary system is dependent mostly on atmospheric pressure. So, the lower air pressure at high altitudes mitigates the amount of O2 absorbed into our blood stream and the amount of CO2 dispersed out of it. Acclimation at altitude encourages an increase in blood cells to meet the O2 demand. Training masks cannot do that.

data.author: Mark Courtenay

data.text: And to share another experience: took a sightseeing flight to 23,000 feet - Mt McKinley. The plane was non-pressurized. I was sitting next the the pilot in the rh seat. I told the pilot I wanted to take off my O2 system and attempt to maintain a conversation. He said ‚Äúsure‚Äù. At this point in my life I had zero acclimatization to altitude. The pilot said I was fine - as near he could tell. But I knew better, I lost my color vision in the first few seconds and when I went back on O2 my vision registered as wow it just got brighter outside. My son, a USCG pilot, has been tested in altitude chambers and some times he is great, with no effects, but other times he can notice a distinct slowing of reflexes when he see him self on video. His instructors told him, ‚Äúhard to predict same person can be fine one day and not so good the next. ‚ÄúDrink plenty of water, that does make a difference ‚Äú.

data.text: I had to train for firefighting and we would do stair master with 40lb pack then either run or bike sprints. I did that and then went to mountains a few days early and did just fine. And, yes, altitude sickness vs shortness of breath are different but being as fit as possible helps. Viagra may also help - ask your doctor. It was used to treat altitude and respiratory illness, too, with an observed side effect.
data.author: Jim Lee

data.text: The most effective way to prevent altitude sensitivity issues is to acclimate right beforehand. Can't rush your body's ability to adapt to changes in air pressure going up high altitudes. Other important on site strategies to help include staying hydrated, use meds like Diamox and ibuprofen, and sleep well. Before the trip, just make sure you're well conditioned. The better shape one is before the trip, the less taxing and demanding the trip will be on the body. Obviously, of course, but that much more important when the trip is at high altitude.
data.author: Aaron Crawford

data.text: When we head to the mountains, we allow a couple of days to acclimate and then the first couple of days are easy ones. Helps my wife with the effects. (High altitude in this case being anything above 6000 feet).

data.text: When I was trekking to higher altitude, I was advised by a Doctor to start taking Diamox 2-3 days before we started trekking. Don‚Äôt do anything beforehand or during the trip that could negatively impact your blood oxygen level, like breathing in exhaust fumes or cooking in your tent (which you should never do anyway!).

data.text: Great question. I‚Äôve just looked at Training for the New Alpinism, which has a good chapter on the topic. In short, they are sceptical as to whether there is much you can do at home. Definitely give yourself time to acclimate and always bike high, sleep low!
